results.name: Cross-Session Recall
results.description: Validates semantic recall of policy decisions across sessions with paraphrased queries

steps.description: Session 1 (Tuesday): User states language constraint with decision record ID and nonce

response.response:
Grounded in project memory (11 snippets).

Okay, got it. Based on the Decision Record ARCH-22B (Nonce N-19C8), the key points are: 1. The project team has firmly decided to use Java only and rejected the use of Python for the integration project. [#1]
2. This decision is final and should not be re-opened. [#2] The implications of this decision are:
- The entire integration layer of the project will be implemented using the Java programming language, which is a widely-used, enterprise-grade language well-suited for this type of application.
- The team will not be able to leverage any Python-based libraries or frameworks, and must rely solely on the Java ecosystem for the integration work.
- This decision limits the flexibility and potential technology choices for the integration, but provides clear direction and constraints for the development team.

memoryCards.label: msg_1768081684554
memoryCards.content:
[Flow:general] User: Policy POLICY-12A (Nonce T3N9): For this project, we have strict technology constraints. AWS and all cloud services are forbidden due to compliance requirements. Budget cap is $50,000. No exceptions.
Assistant: Grounded in project memory (11 snippets).

Okay, based on the information provided in the policies and decision records: 1. Specific points: - The project has a strict $50,000 budget cap [cite: Policy POL-007 (Nonce R8M4)] - AWS and all cloud services are forbidden due to compliance requirements [cite: Policy POLICY-12A (Nonce T3N9)] - The project team has decided to use Java only and rejected the use of Python [cite: Decision Record DR-014 (Nonce Q7F3)] 2. Implications: - The budget cap will limit the resources and technologies that can be used, requiring careful planning and prioritization - The prohibition on cloud services means the project must be implemented using on-premise infrastructure, which can be more time-consuming and costly to maintain and scale - The decision to use Java over Python will impact the technical approach and skillset required for the integration layer of the project

Okay, got it. Based on the Decision Record ARCH-22B (Nonce N-19C8), the key points are: 1. The project team has firmly decided to use Java only and rejected the use of Python for the integration project. [#1]
2. This decision is final and should not be re-opened. [#2] The implications of this decision are:
- The entire integration layer of the project will be implemented using the Java programming language, which is a widely-used, enterprise-grade language well-suited for this type of application.
- The team will not be able to leverage any Python-based libraries or frameworks, and must rely solely on the Java ecosystem for the integration work.
- This decision limits the flexibility and potential technology choices for the integration, but provides clear direction and constraints for the development team.

steps.description: Session 2 (Friday): User asks about language choice, requesting decision record ID and nonce

response.response:
Grounded in project memory (9 snippets).

Based on the information provided in the decision record, the key points are: 1. The project team has decided to use Java exclusively for the integration layer and rejected the use of Python. (Decision Record DR-014, Nonce Q7F3) 2. This is a firm decision that should not be re-opened. Implications:
- The integration layer of the project will be implemented using Java, a widely-used, general-purpose programming language well-suited for enterprise-level applications.
- Python will not be used for the integration layer, even though it is part of the project in other capacities (e.g. a Python simulator). So in summary, the programming language standardized for the integration project is Java, as per Decision Record DR-014 (Nonce Q7F3).
